Body:
I'm working on Windows 10 with Visual Studio 2015 Rc. I developed a Universal App that sends toast notifications. I noticed that when deploying the App on RaspberryP2, I receive this exception:

WinRT information: The notification platform is unavailable.

It's ok, I don't really need to show notifications on the IOT device, I just to make it run without throwing.

The code that throws:

  XmlDocument toastXml = ToastNotificationManager.GetTemplateContent(ToastTemplateType.ToastText02);	  XmlNodeList stringElements = toastXml.GetElementsByTagName(text");	  stringElements[0].AppendChild(toastXml.CreateTextNode("Title"));	  stringElements[1].AppendChild(toastXml.CreateTextNode("Text"));	  ToastNotification toast = new ToastNotification(toastXml);	  ToastNotificationManager.CreateToastNotifier().Show(toast);

How can I avoid to run this code if the App is running on Windows 10 IoT? (I was looking about something like if (NotificationsAvaibible) { } else { }

"
It is marked as part of the Universal API Contract so it should have a non-throwing implementation on IoT. I'll follow up.
@PeterTorr-MSFT This problem still exists with VS 2015 RTM and Windows IoT core 10.0.10556.
Yes, a VS update won't fix anything. You need a fixed IoT build. Not sure when that will be, sorry.

This page shows the unavailable APIs at this time: https://ms-iot.github.io/content/en-US/win10/UnavailableApis.htm

If this doesn't work for your scenario:

if (ApiInformation.IsTypePresent("Windows.ApplicationModel.Background.ToastNotificationActionTrigger"))	  {	     //put your line here which otherwise has an exception	  }

then you may need to resort to try...except for the line.

"
